description: Number of partitions of n in SPM(n): these are the partitions obtained from (n) by iteration of the following transformation: p -> p' if p' is a partition (i.e., decreasing) and p' is obtained from p by removing a unit from the i-th component of p and adding one to the (i+1)-th component, for any i.
comments: The SPM (Sand Pile Model) originated in physics, where it is used as a paradigm for Self-Organized Criticality. Also used in computer science as a model of distributed behavior. It is a special case of Chip Firing Game and more generally it can be viewed as a cellular automaton.It is known that the sets SPM(n) have a lattice structure. An explicit formula is known for the (unique) fixed point of SPM(n), as well as a characterization of the elements of SPM(n).Contribution from _Roger L. Bagula_, Oct 21 2009: (Start)Product[(1+z*q^n),{n,0Infinity}]=Sum[A[n]*z^n=1+Sum[q^(n(n-1)/2)*z^n/Product[(1-q^k),(k,1,n}],{n,1,Infinity}]with recursion:A[n]=q^(n-1)/(1-q^n)*A[n-1]q^(n(n-1)/2)*z^n/Product[(1-q^k),(k,1,n}]=q^(n*(n + 1))/2*Product[q +1/(1 - q^k), {k, 1, n}], {n, 1, Infinity}]One can solve for z:Solve[q^(n(n - 1)/2)*z^n/Product[(1 - q^k), {k, 1, n}] == q^(n*(n + 1))/2*Product[q + 1/(1 - q^k), {k, 1, n}], z]and the recursion is:A[n]=x^n*(x+1/(1+x^n))*A[n-1]For:Sum[A[n],{n,0,Infinity]]=1 + Sum[x^(n*(n + 1))/2*Product[x + 1/(1 -x^k),{k, 1, n}], {n, 1, Infinity}].(End)
